revision.text:
A '''background actor''' or '''extra''' is a [[performer]] in a [[film]], [[television show]], stage, musical, opera or ballet production, who appears in a nonspeaking or nonsinging (silent) capacity, usually in the background (for example, in an audience or busy street scene). [[War film]]s and [[epic film]]s often employ background actors in large numbers: some films have featured hundreds or even thousands of paid background actors as cast members (hence the term "cast of thousands"). Likewise, [[grand opera]] can involve many background actors appearing in spectacular productions.
On a film or TV set, background actors are usually referred to as "atmosphere", "background talent", "background performers", "background artists", "background cast members" or simply "background", while the term "extra" is rarely used.<ref>[http://tophollywoodactingcoach.com/2012/01/background_actors_extra_atmosphere/ Background Actors, Extras or Atmosphere?] ''tophollywoodactingcoach'' Published by Ross, Mae; 3-2-1 Acting. Accessed 22 May 2018</ref> In a stage production, background actors are commonly referred to as "[[supernumeraries]]". In opera and ballet, they are called either "extras" or "supers".
==Casting== Casting criteria for background actors depend on the production. It is not entirely true that background cast members require little or no [[acting]] experience, as any type of unrealistic portrayal must include some form of imagination and acting. Punctuality, reliability and the ability to take direction also figure prominently for these cast members. Background actors are often selected on short notice, after all other preparations for the shoot have been finalized.<ref name="Kelly">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ftbWjFvRMZ4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=extra+actor&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Rs_Upa2IoTtigK2mYHYBQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=extra%20actor&f=false|title=The Truth About Being an Extra: How to Become a Good Background Actor|author=Jo Kelly|publisher=Google Books|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
Several casting agencies specialize only in background work, whilst in the UK the directory ''Contacts'' published annually by [[Spotlight (Casting Services Company)|Spotlight]] lists all accredited agencies and productions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/faqs/about/extra|title=How to be an Extra|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="MMagpie" /> Some agencies charge a registration fee, and some (mostly commercial background casting) will take between 10% and 15% commission from any booked work. Artists may be required to provide a basic one-page A4 sized CV/resume, that states basic personal details and dimensions, any significant skills (e.g. [[stage combat]]), and includes two 8x10 inch photographs on the rear: one head shot; one full body shot.<ref name="Kelly" /><ref name="MMagpie" /><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-10557/How-movie-extra.html|title=How to be a movie extra|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
When hiring background actors, casting directors generally seek those with a specific "look", such as "high school students" or "affluent senior citizens", consistent with the context of the film. Casting directors may also look for background actors with a special skill for the scene, such as [[rollerblading]], or dancing. A background actor is often expected to bring his or her own wardrobe to the set, although there are also "fittings" for a specific scene or period. A casting director may favor the one who already has the required costume or prop, such as a police uniform, or a musical instrument. On other occasions, where a costume has already been prepared (for example, to fit another actor who is now unavailable), a background actor may be selected as a "costume double" simply because they are the right size to fit it. On smaller productions or student films, background actors may be hired ''en masse'' with little formality.<ref name="Kelly" />
The length of a background actor's employment on a production largely depends on the needs of the director and the scenes being filmed. Some background actors are needed on the set only for a day or two, while others may remain with the film for an extended period. For instance, on [[James Cameron]]'s film ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', a group of 150 "core background actors" was hired to play the ship's passengers, and employed throughout the filming.
==Salary and working conditions== {{Globalize|section|date=August 2010}}
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom]], the distinction between an actor and an extra is defined by agreements between the actors [[trade union]]s [[Broadcasting, Entertainment, Cinematograph and Theatre Union|Broadcasting Entertainment Cinematograph and Theatre Union (BECTU)]] and [[Equity (trade union)|Equity]], and the various commercial trade and production bodies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bectu.org.uk/get-involved/background-artistes |title=Background Artistes |publisher=BECTU |date=2011-07-01 |accessdate=2013-03-26}}</ref> These state that once a performer says 13 or more words in any scene, they must become a contracted actor in that production.<ref name="EquityRA" /> Minimum pay rates are defined by UK Government minimum wage regulations, and both BECTU and Equity have agreed rates with each body. However, even on non-union productions an extra's pay is an agreed day-rate for ten hours of production time.<ref name=MMagpie>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneymagpie.com/article/make-money-being-a-film-or-tv-extra|title=Make money being a film or TV extra|publisher=Money Magpie|accessdate=1 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140730221918/http://www.moneymagpie.com/article/make-money-being-a-film-or-tv-extra|archivedate=30 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> All performers under agreement with BECTU/Equity are paid on-going royalties. Hence on many advertisements, which are often shown multiple times and distributed internationally, whilst the extra is paid a contracted day-rate, the largest payment is nominally due from ongoing royalties. Due to the resultant complex calculations from multiple international showings, performers under a union managed agreement are often bought-out of their advertisement royalties with a one-off payment.<ref name="EquityRA">{{cite web|url=http://www.equity.org.uk/resource-centre/rates-and-agreements/|title=Rates and Agreements - Members Guide & Pamphlet|publisher=[[Equity (trade union)|Equity]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
===United States=== In the United States, most major film and television productions used to fall under the jurisdiction of the [[Screen Actors Guild]] (SAG) or [[American Federation of Television and Radio Artists|AFTRA]]. The two unions have merged into [[SAG-AFTRA]].
SAG-signatory [[Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers|producers]] are allowed to hire non-union background actors after a certain number of SAG performers have been cast; non-union background actors are usually paid the minimum wage. On productions outside of union jurisdiction, payment for background actors is at the discretion of the producers, and ranges from [[Trade Union|union]]-scale rates to "copy and credit" (i.e., no pay). Those producers who do not pay their actors may be in violation of state and federal laws about minimum wage for a job.
Between 1946 and 1992, background actors in film and television were largely represented by the '''Screen Extras Guild.''' SEG was disbanded on 1 June 1992 and transferred its jurisdiction to SAG.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1153/is_n8_v115/ai_12624085 Television and movie agreement - collective bargaining agreement; Screen Actors Guild, American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers], Monthly Labor Review, August 1992</ref>
==In popular culture==
The silent film ''[[The Extra Girl]]'' (1923) portrays a small-town girl who comes to [[Hollywood]] and becomes a background actor in her attempt to achieve stardom.
The British television sitcom ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'' (2005–07) follows the exploits of two professional background actors, Andy and Maggie. They spend most of their time on set looking for a speaking role and a boyfriend, respectively.
In the Hindi [[black comedy]] film ''[[Mithya]]'' (2008), the protagonist is a background actor whose facial similarity to an underworld [[Boss (crime)|crime boss]] lands him in trouble.
The Filipino [[comedy-drama]] film ''[[Ekstra]]'' (''The Bit Player'') (2013) centers around the life of a divorcee named Loida Malabanan, whose [[temporary work|odd job]] as a bit player for various acting roles enabled her to send her daughter to college.<ref name=ekstravariety>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/global/the-bit-player-review-toronto-1200607975/|title=Toronto Film Review: ‘The Bit Player’|last=Kuipers|first=Richard|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=September 11, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref> The movie is a [[social commentary]] on the exploitation and mistreatment of the [[marginalized]] sector in the [[television production]] industry in the Philippines.<ref name="ekstra blog">{{cite blog|url=https://said-fred.blogspot.com/2013/07/ekstra-excellent-paradox.html|title=EKSTRA: An Excellent Paradox|last=Hawson|first=Fred|publisher=[[Blogger (service)|Blogger]]|date=July 29, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name=ekstraINQ>{{cite news|url=https://opinion.inquirer.net/59179/ekstra-the-country-in-miniature|title='Ekstra': The country in miniature|last=Jimenez-David|first=Rina|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=August 19, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name=ekstrarev>{{cite blog|url=https://ilusyonaryo.wordpress.com/2014/12/11/a-review-paper-for-ekstra-2013-a-film-by-jeffrey-jeturian/|title=A review paper for Ekstra (2013): A film by Jeffrey Jeturian|<!--author=migibytes-->|website=ilusyonaryo.com|publisher=[[WordPress]]|date=December 11, 2014|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref>
The Chinese-Hong Kong film ''[[I Am Somebody]]'' (2015) is about extras working at the [[Hengdian World Studios]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2015/film/asia/i-am-somebody-review-derek-yee-shanghai-film-festival-1201519295/|title= Film Review: 'I Am Somebody' |first=Maggie |last=Lee |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=10 October 2015 |work=[[variety.com]] }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Background dancer]] * [[Bit part]] * [[Central Casting]] * [[Character actor]] * [[Supporting actor]] * [[Under-Five]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * "[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2005/apr/02/culture.features16 Extra helping]", Sam Delaney, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2 April 2005 {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} {{Film crew}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Extra (Actor)}} [[Category:Stage terminology]] [[Category:Acting]] [[Category:Filmmaking occupations]]

revision.text:
[[File:Eiskrippe 2017 Graz 06.jpg|thumb|Ice nativity scene on 18 December 2017]] The '''ice nativity scene''' ([[German language|German]] ''Eiskrippe'') is an ice sculpture exhibited annually in the Landhaus courtyard in [[Graz]], [[Austria]], during [[Advent]] time. The project of a [[nativity scene]] made of [[glaze ice]] has been a highlight in the town’s Advent scene since 1996 and receives international media attention. == History == [[File:Eiskrippe 2011 Graz 03.jpg|thumb|upright|Ice nativity scene 2011 (detail)]] The first ice nativity scene was modelled in 1996 on behalf of the Graz tourist association. The renowned [[Villach]] ice artist Gert J. Hödl (1943–2017) who had already succeeded in [[Canada]], [[Russia]], [[Norway]] and [[Japan]] came on board for the artistic direction. After two years of planning Hödl alongside four employees carved an ice nativity scene out of 156 blocks with a total weight of 23 tons, a global first. The Landhaus in the city centre was chosen as exhibition site for artwork with life-sized characters. The complete installation was eight meters wide by four meters high.{{cite news|author=Christian Weniger|title=Eine Eiskrippe aus 23 Tonnen Eis für Graz|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=1996-10-29|pages=24–25}} The tourist association kept the project alive for the following years and was first able to provide online live pictures in 1998.{{cite news|title=Eiskrippe auch im Internet|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=1998-11-29|page=1}} Since its first installation the nativity scene is sculpted in late November or early December and revealed in a solemn ceremony. In the evening hours the ice nativity scene and the [[Arcade (architecture)|Arcade halls]] of the Landhaus are colorfully illuminated. To ensure increased durability, bigger blocks were first used in 2003, the year Graz was the [[European Capital of Culture]], and the ice weight rose to 45 tons. The ice also showed a greenish hue for the first time.{{cite news|title=Eiskrippe schimmert heuer grün|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=2003-11-23|page=31}} As a tribute to a famous son of Graz, [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], who had been elected [[Governor of California]] shortly before, Hödl put a bear – the Californian [[heraldic animal]] – in the background of the [[Holy family]], an action that greatly enhanced international media interest.{{cite news|author=Bernd Hecke|title=Bei Krippe ist der Bär los|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=2003-11-29|page=25}} Other actions aimed at slowing down the melting process include a more "[[monument]]al construction" first implemented in 2004 which is supposed to generate an [[Ice house (building)|ice house]] effect.{{cite news|title=Krippe mit Kühlhauseffekt|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=2004-12-04|page=21}} Several sets of characters are stored in an ice house near Graz in case they are required as replacements.{{cite web|title=Das Geheimnis hinter der Eiskrippe|periodical=|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/steiermark/graz/grazumgebung/4613162/GRAZER-ADVENT_Das-Geheimnis-hinter-der-Eiskrippe|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-12-18|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=Michael Saria|date=2014-12-08|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}} Since 2014, [[Finland|Finnish]] ice artist Kimmo Frosti is responsible for the artistic design of the ice nativity scene. With support from a five-man team and [[liquid nitrogen]], it takes him about a week to complete the work. The components are then arranged with the help of a [[forklift]].{{cite web|title=Herr Frosti schnitzt die Grazer Eiskrippe|periodical=|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/steiermark/graz/5124800/Video_Herr-Frosti-schnitzt-die-Grazer-Eiskrippe|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-12-18|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=Michael Saria|date=2016-11-26|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}{{cite web|title=Grazer Eiskrippe aus rund 50 Tonnen Eis aufgebaut|periodical=|publisher=[[Tiroler Tageszeitung]]|url=http://www.tt.com/panorama/gesellschaft/9322730-91/grazer-eiskrippe-aus-rund-50-tonnen-eis-aufgebaut.csp|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-12-18|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=2014-11-28|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}} The ice nativity scene has generated international attention since its first installment. As of 2016, coverage was provided on more than 200 international TV channels and newspapers. [[press agency|Press agencies]] like ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and ''[[Reuters]]'' reported on the project.{{cite web|title=Ice Sculpture of Nativity Scene Created in Graz, Austria By Gert J. Hoedl and Team|periodical=|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/28/ice-sculptors-nativity-graz_n_1116324.html|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-12-18|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=2011-11-28|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}} == Controversy == [[File:Eiskrippe 2009 Graz 01.jpg|thumb|Collapsed artwork 2009]] Despite its value as a tourist attraction there has been debate over the meaningfulness of the ice nativity scene. At warmer temperatures the construction does not always survive throughout the entirety of [[Advent]]. In 2002, the sculpture collapsed before being even opened to the public, and had to be saved by the artist with night work. In 2006,{{cite web|title=Eiskrippe im Landhaushof eingestürzt|periodical=|publisher=[[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]|url=http://stmv1.orf.at/stories/409301|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-12-18|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=2009-12-12|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}} and 2009, the nativity scene did not edndure the warm weather and crumpled before [[Christmas]]. A local politician of the [[The Greens – The Green Alternative|Green Party]] cynically noted:
"Due to global warming, Advent will become ever milder. This raises the question of whether the city of Graz should continue to invest more than 40,000 € in a pool of water."{{cite news|title=Eine Eiskrippe mit Ablaufdatum|publisher=[[Kronen Zeitung]]|language=de|date=2006-12-23|page=27}}
Suggestions to cancel the project have been turned down by the tourist association who argued that the ice nativity scene rendered the economically important Graz Advent an "unmistakable" event.{{cite news|title=Grazer Eiskrippe „gerettet“|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=2005-12-02|page=27}} The ''[[Tiroler Tageszeitung]]'' made tongue-in-cheek claims about yearly bets of Graz citizens on the ice nativity scene’s endurance. A planned wood roof to protect the artwork from rain was vetoed in 1999 through intervention of the [[Federal Monuments Office]] because it would disturb the ambience of the [[Renaissance architecture]]. In the same year there was a conflict of interest with a movie event that wished to keep equipment in place, which nearly prevented the popular artwork’s construction.{{cite news|author=Bernd Hecke|title=Der Eisschnitzer droht, Graz den Rücken zu kehren|publisher=[[Kleine Zeitung]]|language=de|date=1999-11-25|page=25}} == Artistic direction == * 1996–2013: Gert J. Hödl ([[Austria]]) * since 2014: Kimmo Frosti ([[Finland]]) == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [https://www.graztourismus.at/advent/en/christmas-markets/the-ice-nativity-scene_adm-2481 The ice nativity scene on the website of Graz Tourismus] * {{YouTube|VhTonqGkkS0|Creation and opening (2011)}} * [http://www.graz-hauptplatz.at/01adf8982e1229a0d/53732199730df6503/53732198870c93f13/index.html Images of former installments 1996–2010] {{Coordinate|article=/|NS=47.069816|EW=15.439413|type=landmark|region=AT-6}} [[Category:Buildings and structures made of snow or ice]] [[Category:Nativity of Jesus in art]] [[Category:Graz]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Water in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | alt=See adjacent text. | image_file=Chase_William_Merritt_Idle_Hours_1894.jpg | image_size=300px | title=Idle Hours | other_language_1=English | other_title_1= | artist=[[William Merritt Chase]] | year=1894 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil]] on [[canvas]] | height_metric=90.2 | width_metric=64.8 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Fort Worth | museum=Amon Carter Museum of American Art }} '''''Idle Hours''''' is an oil on canvas [[landscape painting]] by the [[American Impressionist]] painter [[William Merritt Chase]]. Completed in 1894, it measures 90.2 by 64.8 centimeters, and is now housed at the [[Amon Carter Museum of American Art]], [[Fort Worth]].<ref>[http://www.cartermuseum.org/artworks/282 Amon Carter Museum of American Art]</ref> It is one of many paintings by Chase that depicted his wife and children at ease.<ref>An American Collection: Works from the Amon Carter Museum {{ISBN|1555951988}}</ref>
==Description== ''Idle Hours'' portrays Chase's wife, sister, and two daughters on the shore at eastern Long Island, where Chase taught a summer school in landscape painting. The artwork incorporates urban subtexts and country retreats in response to urbanization and industrialization.<ref>American Stories: Paintings of Everyday Life, 1765-1915 {{ISBN|1588393364}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Impressionist paintings]] [[Category:Paintings in Fort Worth, Texas]] [[Category:1894 paintings]] [[Category:Water in art]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Books in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Artwork | image_file=Edwin Landseer Trial By Jury.jpg | title=Trial by Jury | artist=Sir Edwin Landseer | year=1840 | medium=Oil-on-canvas | height_metric=72 | width_metric=95 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in }}
'''''Trial by Jury''''', or '''''Laying Down the Law''''' as it is commonly known, is an oil-on-canvas painting from [[1840 in art|1840]] by the English painter [[Sir Edwin Landseer]], which satirises the legal profession. It depicts dogs in the roles of members of the court with a [[poodle|French poodle]] centre stage as the judge. The painting was inspired by a chance comment by a judge, while at dinner with Landseer, that the French poodle belonging to amateur artist and renowned socialite, the [[Alfred Guillaume Gabriel, Count D'Orsay|Count d'Orsay]], "would make a capital Lord Chancellor".
Landseer was a member of the [[Royal Academy]] and had become famous for his paintings and drawings of animals. His later works include ''[[Monarch of the Glen (painting)|The Monarch of the Glen]]'', an iconic and much-reproduced painting of a stag in the [[Scottish Highlands|Highlands]], and the sculptures of the lions at the foot of [[Nelson's Column]] in [[Trafalgar Square]], [[London]].
He completed ''Trial by Jury'' in 1840 — it was exhibited at the Royal Academy in the same year and was acquired by [[William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire]], who had Landseer add his [[spaniel|Blenheim spaniel]], Bony, into the scene behind the [[greyhound]]. Early copies of the painting can be seen with Bony absent. The original now hangs in the Sculpture Gallery at [[Chatsworth House]]. The poodle has been variously identified as representing [[Lord Brougham]], who had been [[Lord Chancellor]] from 1830 to 1834, or [[Lord Lyndhurst]], who had held the post three times (1827–1830, 1834–1835, and 1841–1846).
==See also== *''[[Dogs Playing Poker]]''
==References== {{refbegin}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.chatsworth.org/learning/art_highlights.htm |title=The arts collection and archives: Highlights |publisher=Chatsworth |date=2006 |accessdate=26 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061006034050/http://www.chatsworth.org/learning/art_highlights.htm |archivedate= 6 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.the-kennel-club.org.uk/gallery/catalogue/sc936115.shtml |title=Oil Paintings:Laying Down The Law |publisher=The Kennel Club |accessdate=26 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060112150118/http://www.the-kennel-club.org.uk/gallery/catalogue/sc936115.shtml |archivedate=January 12, 2006 }} {{refend}}

revision.comment: capitalization fixes
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} [[File:Line of purples.png|thumb|right|200px|The line of purples circled on the CIE chromaticity diagram]] In [[color theory]], the '''line of purples''' or '''purple boundary''' is the locus on the edge of the [[chromaticity|chromaticity diagram]] formed between extreme spectral [[red]] and [[violet (color)|violet]]. Except for these endpoints of the Line, colors on the Line are non-spectral, i. e., no monochromatic light source can generate them; rather, every color on the Line is a mixture in a ratio, unique to that color, of fully saturated red and fully saturated violet, these two spectral colors being the endpoints of visibility on the [[Electromagnetic spectrum|spectrum]] of pure [[hue|hues]]. Colors on the Line and [[spectral color]]s are the only ones that are fully [[Colorfulness|saturated]] in the sense that, for any point on the Line, no other possible color being a mixture of red and violet is more saturated than it. Unlike spectral colors, which may be implemented, for example, by the nearly monochromatic [[light]] of a [[laser]], with precision much finer than [[MacAdam ellipse|human chromaticity resolution]], colors on the Line are more difficult to depict. The sensitivity of each type of human [[cone cell]] to ''both'' spectral red and spectral violet, being at the opposite endpoints of the Line and at the extremes of the visible spectrum, is very low. (See [[luminosity function]]) Therefore, common purple colors are not highly bright. The line of purples, a theoretical boundary of chromaticity, is distinct from "[[purple]]s", a more general denomination of colors, which also refers to less than fully saturated colors (see [[shades of purple]] and [[shades of pink]] for examples) that form the interior of a [[triangle]] between [[white point|white]] and the line of purples in the [[CIE chromaticity diagram]]. == In color spaces == In [[three-dimensional space|3-dimensional]] [[color space]]s the Line, if present, becomes a [[surface (mathematics)|2-dimensional shape]]. For example, in the [[CIE XYZ]] it is a [[plane (geometry)|planar]] sector bounded by black–red and black–violet rays. In systems premised on pigment colors, such as the [[Munsell color system|Munsell]] and [[Pantone Matching System|Pantone]] systems, boundary purples might be absent because the maximally possible [[lightness]] of a pigment vanishes when its chromaticity approaches the Line, such that purple pigments near the Line are indistinguishable from [[black]]. The [[RGB color model]], although ''theoretically'' capable of approximating the colors of the Line because it is an [[additive color|additive]] system, usually practically fails because of the limitations of the light source used. The boundary of [[sRGB]] (pictured) runs approximately parallel to the Line, connecting the [[primary color|primaries]] [[red]] and [[blue (RGB)|(color wheel) blue]], and thus purples near the Line are absent from the [[gamut]] of sRGB. [[Magenta]] ink, which is one of [[CMYK color model|CMYK]]'s primaries, is also very distant from the Line for the reason explained above. The [[wide-gamut RGB color space]] approximates the colors on the Line better, but devices capable of displaying colors with this enhanced system are prohibitively expensive for ordinary consumers. == Table of highly saturated purples == Most of the names of the purple colors in the table below do not denominate colors on the line of purples, but instead are slightly less than maximally [[colorfulness|colorful]], i. e. [[Colorfulness#Saturation|saturated]]. {|class=wikitable align="center" cellpadding=2 ![[Name]]s!!Sample ! [[Hue]] ![[Complementary colors|Complementary]]
(see [[spectral color#Table of spectral or near-spectral colors|the table]]) |- |Far spectral violet, ≈ Blue ([[CIE 1931 color space|CIE RGB]]) | bgcolor="#3F007F" align=center |[[#×|×]] | align="right" |≈ 260° |[[spectral color#Lime|≈ Yellow/Lime]] |- |Non-spectral [[violet (color)|violet]] | bgcolor="#55007F" align=center |  | align="right" |≈ 270° |≈ Lime |- |Purple 5P ([[Munsell color system|Munsell]])http://www.cis.rit.edu/research/mcsl2/online/munsell_data/all.dat (these values were possibly extrapolated, not measured on real dyes) and [[commons:File:CIE1931xy blank.svg]] for V = 3, C = 38 | bgcolor="#9900CC" align=center |[[#×|×]] | align="right" |≈ 280° |[[spectral color#Green|≈ Chartreuse green]] |- |[[Electric purple]] ([[sRGB]]) | bgcolor="#BF00FF" align=center |  | align="right" |285° |≈ Harlequin |- |[[Phlox (color)|Phlox]] | bgcolor="#DF00FF" align=center |  | align="right" |292° |  ⋮ |- |[[Fuchsia (color)|Fuchsia]] / [[Magenta]] (sRGB [[secondary color|secondary]]) | bgcolor="#FF00FF" align=center |  | align="right" |300° |Green ([[sRGB]] primary) |- | align=center |? | bgcolor="#FF00D0" align=center |  |  ? |[[Green]] (traditional)/[[Emerald (color)|Emerald]] |- |[[CMYK color model|Process]] magenta | bgcolor="#FF0090" align=center |  | align="right" |320° |  ⋮ |- |Magenta dye, ≈ [[Tyrian purple]] | bgcolor="#CA1F7B" align=center |  | align="right" |327° |  ⋮ |- |[[Rose (color)|Rose]] | bgcolor="#FF007F" align=center |  | align="right" |330° |≈ Spring green |- |[[Raspberry (color)|Raspberry]], ≈ [[Ruby (color)|Ruby]] |bgcolor="#E30B5C" align=center |  |align="right" |337° |  ⋮ |- | colspan=3 |  | rowspan=2 vaign=center |Green (NCS) |- |Red ([[Natural Color System|NCS]]) | bgcolor="#C40233" align=center |  | align="right" |345° |- |[[Crimson]] (may be partially outside sRGB) | bgcolor="#C0002F" align=center |  | align="right" |≈ 345° |≈ Green 5G (Munsell) |- |[[Carmine (color)|Carmine]]The name extends towards spectral colors. | bgcolor="#C40028" align=center |[[#×|×]] | align="right" |≈ 350°–0° |Turquoise/Cyan |- |Red 5R (Munsell) for V = 4, C = 24 | bgcolor="#C40020" align=center |[[#×|×]] | align="right" |≈ 354° |  ⋮ |- |Extreme spectral red / Red (CIE RGB) | bgcolor="#C40011" align=center |[[#×|×]] | align="right" |≈ 359° |Cyan |} {{visible anchor|×}} Approximations of colors outside sRGB. ==See also== * [[Complementary wavelength]] * [[Purple#Vs. violet|Purple versus violet]] ==Notes and references== *Kenneth L. Kosanke, B. J. Kosanke, ''The Illustrated Dictionary of Pyrotechnics'', p. 72 {{Reflist}} == External links == * HyperPhysics: [http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/HBASE/vision/colper.html "Color Perception"] *Spectra software and databases: https://web.archive.org/web/20110409161524/http://spectra.at.tut.by/en/page0.html [[Category:Color]]

page.title: List of most-streamed songs on Spotify

revision.comment: /* 100 Most Streamed Songs */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Ed Sheeran 2013.jpg|130px|thumb|right|"[[Shape of You]]" by [[Ed Sheeran]] (pictured) is the most streamed song on [[Spotify]] with over 1.9 billion streams.]] This '''list of most-streamed songs on Spotify''' contains the top 100 songs with the most [[streaming media|streams]] of all time, as derived from [[Spotify]] charts. As of November 2018, 17 songs have exceeded 1 billion streams, with [[Ed Sheeran]]'s "[[Shape of You]]" ranked in the top position.{{cite news|url=https://open.spotify.com/artist/7Jrs1sfr7ID7jqpvDU35Wt?autoplay=true&v=A/|title=Ed Sheeran's Shape of You is now Spotify's most-streamed song of all time|date=22 September 2017|work=Music Business Worldwide|accessdate=30 September 2017}} Prior to November 2013, Spotify's most streamed song was "[[Radioactive (Imagine Dragons song)|Radioactive]]" by [[Imagine Dragons]];{{cite web|url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/4482/20140228/avicii-wake-up-become-streamed-song-spotify-history.htm|title=Avicii and 'Wake Me Up!' become most-streamed song in Spotify history|date=28 February 2014|work=Music Times|accessdate=28 October 2016}} it was overtaken by [[Avicii]]'s "[[Wake Me Up (Avicii song)|Wake Me Up]]", which became the first song to hit 200 million streams on 27 November, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/digital-and-mobile/5922816/aviciis-wake-me-up-is-spotifys-most-played-song-ever|title=Avicii's 'Wake Me Up' is Spotify's Most-Played Song Ever|last=Book|first=Ryan|date=27 February 2014|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=28 October 2016}} "Wake Me Up" held the streaming record for over a year before being surpassed on 22 February, 2015 by Sheeran's "[[Thinking Out Loud]]",{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/spotify/comments/36we2t/thinking_out_loud_by_ed_sheeran_has_just/|title=Thinking Out Loud by Ed Sheeran has just surpassed Wake Me Up by Avicii as the most played song ever on Spotify|date=22 May 2015|work=[[Reddit]]|accessdate=28 October 2016}} which became the first song to hit 500 million streams on 12 July, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6723002/ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-spotify-500-million-streams|title=Ed Sheeran's 'Thinking Out Loud' Becomes First Song to Hit 500 Million Spotify Streams|last=Weiner|first=Natalie|date=12 October 2015|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=28 October 2016}} A month later, however, it was surpassed by [[Major Lazer]] and [[DJ Snake]]'s "[[Lean On]]", featuring [[MØ]],{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/6760813/major-lazer-lean-on-spotify-most-streamed-song-all-time|title=Major Lazer & DJ Snake's 'Lean On' Becomes Spotify's Most-Streamed Song of All Time|last=Rishty|first=David|date=11 November 2015|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=28 October 2016}} which held the streaming record for 11 months until [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]'s "[[One Dance]]", featuring [[Wizkid (musician)|Wizkid]] and [[Kyla (British singer)|Kyla]], overtook it on 18 October, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7549029/drakes-one-dance-spotify-most-streamed-song-ever|title=Drake's 'One Dance' is Spotify's Most-Streamed Song Ever|last=Stutz|first=Colin|date=18 October 2016|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=28 October 2016}} "One Dance" held the streaming record for almost a year before being surpassed by "Shape of You" on 21 September, 2017. As of October 2018, the artists with the most singles in the top 100 are [[Justin Bieber]], with a total of 8 singles (3 solo and 5 featured), and [[Ed Sheeran]] and [[The Chainsmokers]] each with 5 singles, and [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] with 5 singles (4 solo and 1 featured). The fastest song to reach 1 billion streams on Spotify is "Shape of You", doing so in 153 days.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7825481/ed-sheeran-shape-of-you-one-billion-spotify|title=Ed Sheeran's 'Shape of You': One Billion Spotify Plays|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|date=8 June 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=13 June 2017}} As of October 2018, the albums with the most songs in the top 100 are Bieber's ''[[Purpose (Justin Bieber album)|Purpose]]'', with 4, and Sheeran's ''[[÷ (album)|÷]]'' and Drake's ''[[Views (album)|Views]]'' with 3 each. ==100 Most Streamed Songs== The following table lists the top 100 most streamed songs on Spotify, with streams rounded to the nearest million, as well as the artist(s), the album it is currently published to Spotify on, and the date it was originally published to Spotify. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} [[File:Artan, Louis.jpg|thumb|200px|Louis Artan (1870s)]] '''Louis Victor Antonio Artan de Saint-Martin''' (20 April 1837, [[The Hague]] – 23 May 1890, [[Nieuwpoort, Belgium|Nieuwpoort]])<ref>Profile @ the [[Rijksbureau voor Kunsthistorische Documentatie]].</ref> was a Dutch-Belgian painter and etcher who specialized in [[seascape]]s.
==Biography== He came from a noble family. His father was an army officer who served as an [[adjutant]] to [[Prince Frederick of the Netherlands|Prince Frederick]]. In 1842, his family moved to [[Ixelles]] and acquired Belgian citizenship, but his father died later that same year, so they moved to Brussels. [[File:Louis Artan - Marine met vissersbootjes.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Seascape with Fishing Boats]] He began training for a military career, but quit when he was twenty and spent the next six years travelling through the [[Ardennes]], making nature studies. During this time, he became friends with [[Edouard Delvaux]] and, after 1858, began visiting Paris, where he was influenced by the [[Barbizon school]] and the French marine painter, [[Eugène Boudin]]. Although he took some lessons from Delvaux, he remained largely self-taught.<ref name="B">[http://balat.kikirpa.be/peintres/Detail_notice.php?id=99 Biographical notes] @ Dictionnaire des peintres belges.</ref>
He returned to Belgium in 1860, married the following year, and settled in Ixelles. There, he was further influenced by the landscape painter [[Hippolyte Boulenger]], who took him on a tour of the [[Sonian Forest]] in [[Tervuren]]. In 1864, an economic depression resulted in the loss of his family fortune and he had to depend entirely upon painting for his income.
Despite this, he remained restless and spent the years 1867-1868 exploring [[Brittany]] and the shores of the [[English Channel]]. When he returned home, he became one of the sixteen co-founders the [[Société Libre des Beaux-Arts]], an association opposed to the stylistic hegemony of the academies and salons.<ref name="B" /> [[File:Louis Artan016.jpg|thumb|300px|Stranded Boats at Night]] From 1873 to 1874, he lived in [[Antwerp]], where he joined with a group of progressive painters who were fighting the influence of the [[Royal Academy of Fine Arts (Antwerp)|Academy of Fine Arts]]. In 1875, he shared a studio with [[Félicien Rops]] in Paris, then settled briefly in [[Berck-sur-Mer]], where he created some of his best-known works. After 1880, he worked in a more [[Impressionism|impressionistic]] style. In 1881, he became a Knight in the [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Order of Leopold]]. Two years later, he was awarded a gold medal at the [[International Colonial and Export Exhibition]] in Amsterdam.
He spent his last years living in [[De Panne]] and died nearby in Nieuwpoort, of [[influenza]], at the age of fifty-three. His tombstone was designed by [[Victor Horta]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Vera Lewijse, ''De wereld van Louis Artan de Saint Martin. Den Haag 1837-Oostduinkerke 1890'', Doctoral thesis, [[Free University of Brussels]], 2001-2002
==External links== {{Commons category|Louis Artan}} *[http://www.artnet.com/artists/louis-artan-de-saint-martin/past-auction-results ArtNet: More works by Artan]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Artan de Saint-Martin, Louis}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1890 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Belgian painters]] [[Category:Artists from The Hague]] [[Category:Marine artists]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of Belgium]] [[Category:People from The Hague]] [[Category:Deaths from the 1889–90 flu pandemic]]

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox book | name = Love Among the Walnuts: or How I Saved My Family from Being Poisoned | image = Love Among the Walnuts cover.jpg | alt = A black cover with the book's title and a chicken on it. | caption = The cover of the first edition of ''Love Among the Walnuts'' | author = [[Jean Ferris]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Young adult fiction|Young adult novel]] | publisher = [[Harcourt (publisher)|Harcourt]] | pub_date = September 1, 1998 | media_type = Print ([[paperback]]) | pages = 228 | isbn = 978-0-15-206227-9 | oclc = | congress = }}
'''''Love Among the Walnuts: or How I Saved My Family from Being Poisoned'''''{{efn|Some sources list the book's title as ''Love Among the Walnuts: or How I Saved My Entire Family from Being Poisoned''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=James|first1=Helen Foster|title=Author Day Adventures: Bringing Literacy to Life with an Author Visit|date=2002|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Lanham, MD|isbn=0-8108-4370-6|page=98}}</ref>}} is a [[farce|farcical]], [[satire|satirical]] [[Young adult fiction|young adult novel]] with [[fairy tale]] elements written by [[Jean Ferris]]. The story revolves around a young man, Sandy, whose family is poisoned by his scheming uncles in a bid to gain the family fortune. He moves them to Walnut Manor, a neighboring [[convalescent home]], where, with the help of the nurse Sunnie, he tries to save his family and benefit the manor's misunderstood residents.
''Love Among the Walnuts'' was first published on September 1, 1998, by [[Harcourt (publisher)|Harcourt]]. Reviews of the work have been mostly positive, with focus on the story's style and tone. It was listed as a [[YALSA Best Book for Young Adults]] and placed third on the ranked Teens' Top Ten Books list, both in 1999.
==Plot== Horatio Alger Huntington-Ackerman, a successful businessperson, marries Mousey Huntington-Ackerman (née Malone), a striving actor, and has a child named Sandy. They move with their butler Bentley and his wife Flossie to a new country estate called Eclipse with no neighbors except the residents of Walnut Manor, a [[convalescent home]]. One evening when Sandy is a young adult, his uncles Bart and Bernie visit Eclipse. The uncles feed the family a poisoned birthday cake in an attempt to inherit the family fortune, sending everyone but Sandy and Bentley into a coma.
A court ruling mandates that a doctor be present to oversee care for the comatose patients ("the sleepers"). To meet this requirement, Sandy moves them next door to Walnut Manor. There, he meets Dr. Waldemar, the director of the facility, and Sunnie Stone, a nurse hired to care for the sleepers. While Bentley researches a cure of the sleepers' comas, Sandy and Sunnie acquaint themselves with the other patients of Walnut Manor and ultimately fall in love with one another.
With the help of Dr. Waldemar and the manor's residents, Sandy and Sunnie discover that Walnut Manor's patients were placed in the facility's care by their relatives, who, as Walnut Manor's board of directors, have been embezzling from the home. They expose the board of directors' misdeeds and Bentley revives the sleepers from their coma. Sandy, Sunnie, Dr. Waldemar, and the residents of Walnut Manor together thwart Bart and Bernie and send them to prison.
==Publication and genre== ''Love Among the Walnuts'' was first published on September 1, 1998, by [[Harcourt (publisher)|Harcourt]].<ref name="kirkus">{{cite news|title=Love Among the Walnuts|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/jean-ferris/love-among-the-walnuts/|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=[[Kirkus Reviews]]|date=August 1, 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702191005/https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/jean-ferris/love-among-the-walnuts/|archivedate=July 2, 2016}}</ref> Reviewers recommended various appropriate reading ranges, including ages 12–14 and ages 10 and older.<ref name="kirkus" /><ref name="pwreview">{{cite web|title=Love Among the Walnuts|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-15-201590-9|website=[[Publishers Weekly]]|accessdate=July 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307082311/http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-15-201590-9|archivedate=March 7, 2015|date=September 1998}}</ref>
The novel has been characterized as a [[farce]], [[satire]], and [[fairy tale]].<ref name="pwreview" /><ref name="alan">{{cite news|last1=Cleary|first1=Patti|title=Love Among the Walnuts by Jean Ferris|url=http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/ejournals/ALAN/fall98/clip.html|accessdate=June 3, 2016|work=[[The ALAN Review]]|date=Fall 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151024045610/http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/ejournals/ALAN/fall98/clip.html|archivedate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Alethea K. Helbig and Agnes Regan Perkins wrote that story's exploration of familial greed was "in the style of a Victorian melodrama"<ref name="dictionary">{{cite book|last1=Helbig|first1=Alethea K.|last2=Perkins|first2=Agnes Regan|title=Dictionary of American Young Adult Fiction, 1997–2001: Books of Recognized Merit|date=2004|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, CT|isbn=0-313-32430-1|pages=206–207|ref={{harvid|Helbig & Perkins|2004}}}}</ref> and Connie Tyrrell Burns, in ''[[School Library Journal]]'', described the story as "a British farce without the off-color humor".<ref name="burns">{{cite news|last1=Burns|first1=Connie Tyrrell|title=Love Among the Walnuts|url=https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=[[School Library Journal]]|date=August 1, 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702060136/https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|archivedate=July 2, 2016|via=[[Washington County Cooperative Library Services]]}}</ref> In their review of young adult literature that had received recognition by major literary publications between 1997 and 2001, Helbig and Perkins described ''Love Among the Walnuts'' as one of few recognized titles with humorous elements.{{sfn|Helbig & Perkins|2004|p=xxi}} They described the central theme of the novel as "the value to personal and group well-being of loving-kindness and caring".<ref name="dictionary" />
==Reception== ''Love Among the Walnuts'' received mostly positive reviews. Helbig and Perkins commented that "the large cast consists of individualized, complementary, and affectionately handled characters" and the novel's themes "are conveyed with skill and invention".<ref name="dictionary" /> ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' praised the story for its "cast of offbeat characters and some punchy dialogue" while writing that its "plot will have more appeal for adults than children."<ref name="pwreview" /> In ''[[The Horn Book Magazine]]'', Anne St. John commented that Sandy's "emotional responses and internal struggles will ring true with teenagers who are coming of age in a time of turmoil".<ref name="horn">{{cite news|last1=St. John|first1=Anne|title=Love Among the Walnuts|url=https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=[[The Horn Book Magazine]]|date=January 1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702060136/https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|archivedate=July 2, 2016|via=[[Washington County Cooperative Library Services]]}}</ref> According to Elaine McGuire of ''[[Voice of Youth Advocates]]'', ''Love Among the Walnuts'' is "dripping with charm but never cloying ... a fabulous book with lots of lessons about our sickeningly fast-paced '90s lifestyles."<ref name="voya">{{cite news|last1=McGuire|first1=Elaine|title=Love Among the Walnuts|url=https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=[[Voice of Youth Advocates]]|date=February 1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702060136/https://catalog.wccls.org/Mobile/BakerAndTaylor/Review?ISBN=0152015906&UPC=&position=1|archivedate=July 2, 2016|via=[[Washington County Cooperative Library Services]]}}</ref> Paula Rohrlick, writing in ''Kliatt'', compared ''Love Among the Walnuts'' favorably to Ferris's later work, ''Once Upon a Marigold'', describing both stories as "madcap".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rohrlick|first1=Paula|title=Ferris, Jean. Once upon a marigold|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-107202643.html|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=Kliatt|date=November 1, 2002|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
For certain reviewers, the tone and style reinforced the novel's quality. In ''School Library Journal'', Burns commented that ''Love Among the Walnuts'' "is intentionally melodramatic, coincidental, improbable, and hilarious. The restrained, tongue-in-cheek tone heightens the humor of this spoof."<ref name="burns" /> ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' compared the tone and plot of the story to that of a film directed by [[Preston Sturges]] or [[Frank Capra]], describing how it "has an unconventional style and offbeat sense of humor that will delight readers or exhaust them, depending on their tolerance for screwball comedies."<ref name="kirkus" /> Nancy Hinkel, then Associate Editor at Alfred A. Knopf and Crown Books for Young Readers, wrote that the story has "great writing, original ideas, and real style" as well as "a good dose of dry humor that slips past if you're not paying attention."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hinkel|first1=Nancy|title=Would That It Were Mine ... |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20010212/25538-would-that-it-were-mine.html|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=[[Publishers Weekly]]|date=February 12, 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702062511/http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20010212/25538-would-that-it-were-mine.html|archivedate=July 2, 2016}}</ref> Helbig and Perkins described the novel's style as "fast moving, engaging, and witty."<ref name="dictionary" />
Several reviews indicated reservations in recommending ''Love Among the Walnuts''. ''Publishers Weekly'' wrote that "Sandy's accelerated growth from a baby in the nursery to an adult smitten with Sunny (in the space of a chapter) early on in the novel leaves young readers little to identify with."<ref name="pwreview" /> ''Kirkus Reviews'' commented that "a financial subplot and a muddle of characters, defined by their eccentricities, clog the pacing"<ref name="kirkus" /> of the story while St. John in ''The Horn Book Magazine'' said that "some of the characters are two-dimensional".<ref name="horn" />
''Love Among the Walnuts'' was one of 50 fiction titles selected as a 1999 [[Young Adult Library Services Association]] (YALSA) [[YALSA Best Book for Young Adults|Best Book for Young Adults]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Best Books for Young Adults|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-30515036.html|accessdate=July 2, 2016|work=Teacher Librarian|date=March 1, 1999|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> and was ranked third (after [[J. K. Rowling]]'s ''[[Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone]]'' and [[Louis Sachar]]'s ''[[Holes (novel)|Holes]]'') on YALSA's list of Teens' Top Ten Books of 1999.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tuccillo|first1=Diane P.|title=The Library Connection: Teens Meeting the Challenge: Young Adults Gain a Voice Deciding What's Hot to Read|journal=[[The ALAN Review]]|date=Winter 2004|volume=31|issue=2|pages=23–26|doi=10.21061/alan.v31i2.a.4|doi-access=free}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Portal|Children and Young Adult Literature}} {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1998 American novels]] [[Category:American children's novels]] [[Category:Satirical novels]] [[Category:Harcourt (publisher) books]] [[Category:Nursing homes]] [[Category:Death in fiction]] [[Category:1998 children's books]]

revision.text:
The '''Michle Madonna''' is the work of an unknown sculptor called the "Master of the Michle Madonna" who probably worked in [[Brno]] or [[Prague]] during the second third of the 14th century. The name of the sculpture, brought from Brno in 1856,<ref>Hrabovská, 2008, p. 44</ref> relates to its non-original location in the parish church in Michle from where it was purchased by the [[National Gallery in Prague]]. [[File:Michelská madona, Národní galerie v Praze.jpg|thumb|''Michle Madonna'', [[National Gallery in Prague]]]]
== Description and context == The sculpture of the Michle Madonna is 120 cm tall and is carved from pear wood. It bears traces of polychromy. It is the most important example of the linear-rhythmic style of carving, dating from the second quarter of the 14th century in the Czech lands. This style is characterised by drapery that clings to a cylindrical torso in low, sagging pleats that have a decorative and finely drawn character, as does the linen cloth and locks of hair. The legs of the figure of the Madonna in [[contrapposto|contrapose]] are clearly distinguished between the standing and loose one. The child is resting on the Madonna’s jutting right side, towards which both the vertical and horizontal folds of the clothes converge, thus emphasising the bond between the mother and child. The lower position of the child enables the mother’s head to bow more, thereby making the sculptural composition more enclosed. The [[Christ Child|Infant Jesus]]’s hands have not survived but it is clear that he is making a [[blessing]], and is thus not turned towards his mother but towards the faithful.<ref>Hrabovská, 2008, pp. 18-19</ref>
The Michle Madonna’s formal conception has much in common with the linear style of [[Gothic art#Sculpture|French stone sculpture]] of the first third of the 14th century (such as the sculpture of five apostles from the Church of St Jacques-aux-Pèlerins and the tomb sculptures of French kings at [[Basilica of St Denis|St Denis]])<ref>Homolka, 2005, pp. 297-298</ref> that could have been mediated to the Czech context through the [[Rhineland]]. Sculptures of this style are typified by stylisation of shapes and a dense schematic linear pleating of the drapery in both standing and reclining figures. The objective details and wealth of decoration, precisely observed and reproduced, are striking. The group of wooden sculptures related to the Michle Madonna were also originally covered with polychromy, gilding and embossing.
The distinct abstracting style of the workshop of the "Master of the Michle Madonna" gradually absorbed the impulses of contemporary panel painting that was oriented more towards Italian models – the head of the Michle Madonna bears a striking resemblance to the "Madonna of Veveří". It was characterised by a greater emphasis on the physical volume of the figures and the realistic depiction of details. The workshop also produced other Moravian Madonnas (such as the "Madonna of Velké Meziříčí", the small "Apostle of Veverská Bitýška", the "Znojmo Madonna" and the "Prostějov Madonna"). Late works ascribed to the workshop of the "Master of the Michle Madonna" prefigured the abandoning of linear formalism that was accompanied by the effort to achieve specific form and greater naturalism.
== Notes == <references />
== References == * Fajt J, Chlumská Š, Čechy a střední Evropa 1220-1550, Národní galerie v Praze 2014, {{ISBN|978-80-7035-569-5}}, pp. 20–21 * Mistr Michelské madony - druhý život; Katalog vystavených děl Mistra Michelské madony, in: David Majer (ed.), Král, který létal. Moravsko-slezské pomezí v kontextu středoevropského prostoru doby Jana Lucemburského, Ostrava 2011, pp. 433–450, 451–472. * Tereza Hrabovská, Master of the Michle Madonna and his workshop, Bachelor´s dissertation, Catholic Theological Fac., Institute of the History of Christian Art, Prague 2008 (en. summary) * Jaromír Homolka: K některým problémům českého sochařství 14.století, in: Jan Royt/ Michaela Ottová/ Aleš Mudra: Regnum Bohemiae et Sacrum Romanum Imperium, Sborník k poctě Jiřího Kuthana, Praha 2005, pp. 297–298 * Albert Kutal, Jaromír Homolka: Mistr Michelské madony. Madona s dítětem a Apoštol, in: Jaroslav Pešina: České umění gotické 1350-1420, Praha 1970, pp. 127–132 * Albert Kutal: Sochařství, in: Jaroslav Pešina: České umění gotické 1350-1420, Praha 1970, pp. 113–114 * Albert Kutal: České gotické sochařství 1350-1450, Praha, 1962
== External links == * [http://www.rozhlas.cz/leonardo/historie/_zprava/tajemstvi-mistra-michelske-madony--863598 Secret of the Master of the Michle Madonna, Czech radio Leonardo, 2011]

page.title: Max Schmitt in a Single Scull

revision.comment: /* The Reception */ italicizing titles of periodicals per [[MOS:ITALICTITLE]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Max Schmitt in a Single Scull.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 350px | title = Max Schmitt in a Single Scull | artist = [[Thomas Eakins]] | caption = G-44. | year = 1871 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 82.6 | width_metric = 117.5 | height_imperial = {{frac|32|1|2}} | width_imperial = {{frac|46|1|4}} | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[New York City]] | museum = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] }} '''''Max Schmitt in a Single Scull''''' (also known as '''''The Champion Single Sculls''''' or '''''The Champion, Single Sculls''''') is an 1871 painting by [[Thomas Eakins]], [[List of works by Thomas Eakins|Goodrich catalogue #44]]. It is in the permanent collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. Set on the [[Schuylkill River]] in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], it celebrates the victory of Eakins's friend Max Schmitt in the October 5, 1870, [[single scull]]s competition. ==The Sculler== [[File:Detail 3 max schmitt in a single scull thomas eakins.jpeg|thumb|left|Detail of Schmitt. Note the [[Racing shell#Riggers|riggers]].]] Max Schmitt (1843–1900) had attended [[Central High School (Philadelphia)|Philadelphia Central High School]] with Eakins, and the two were close friends. Schmitt was a member of the [[Pennsylvania Barge Club]] – as, it is presumed, was Eakins – one of nine men's clubs in the [[Schuylkill Navy]], and twelve that rowed on the river. The Schuylkill Navy had been organized in 1858, with approximately 300 members, and began hosting annual regattas in 1859 (with a four-year hiatus for the [[American Civil War]]). Initially, the races were for 6-oared and 4-oared [[Cornish pilot gig|gigs]] and barges, but a new kind of lightweight craft was rapidly gaining popularity: the [[racing shell|racing scull]]. Sculls, or shells, were narrower, longer, and a lot faster. Gigs had their [[oarlock]]s mounted on the sides (like a rowboat), but sculls had them a couple feet outside the boat thanks to [[Racing shell#Riggers|riggers]], triangular braces that projected out from the sides. This increased the efficiency of every stroke, and led to much longer oars. Meanwhile, boats got longer and hulls got narrower, until they were as narrow as was possible while still retaining sufficient buoyancy and balance. Schmitt was an early convert to sculls, and owned his own, named "Josie" after his sister. The name of the scull is visible in the painting just below Schmitt's right hand. In September 1866, the Schuylkill Navy's annual regatta first featured a single-sculls race (3 miles, 1 turn), and Schmitt won it. He won again in July 1867, but in September came in second to another Pennsylvania Barge rower in a longer (4 miles, 1 turn) race. He did not participate in 1868, when fellow Pennsylvania Barge rowers won first and second. Schmitt won the single-sculls title again in June 1869, but in September came in second to an [[Undine Barge Club]] rower. ==The Race== [[File:Schuylkill river.jpeg|thumb|Schuylkill River Rowing Course (1872).]] In 1870 the four top rowers in the Schuylkill Navy all belonged to the Pennsylvania Barge Club: Schmitt; Charles Brossman (who had won the title in 1868, and beaten Schmitt in the 4-mile race in September 1867); Austin Street (who had placed second in 1868); and John Lavens, Jr. They were the four competitors in the October championship race. The course was 3 miles long: beginning near Turtle Rock ([[Turtle Rock Light]] is the lighthouse at the northwest end of [[Boathouse Row]]), proceeding upriver under the [[Girard Avenue Bridge|Girard Avenue]] and [[Pennsylvania Railroad, Connecting Railway Bridge|Pennsylvania Railroad Connecting Bridges]] to a stake near the [[Columbia Railroad Bridge]], making a 180-degree turn around the stake, and then heading downriver back to the starting line. [[Image:Max schmitt schreiber and son.jpeg|thumb|Max Schmitt (circa 1871).]]
"Starting well together, Schmitt soon drew ahead followed by Street, Brossman and Lavens. When under the Girard Avenue Bridge, Brossman and Street fouled, the oars of one resting on the boat of the other. Schmitt was now three full lengths ahead. Street and Brossman again fouled in the attempt of the former to turn the eastern stake, thus crossing Brossman's bow. Schmitt had no trouble in maintaining the advantage he had gained, and won easily."Heilman, p. 134.
Schmitt not only re-established himself as the pre-eminent rower on the [[Schuylkill River]], he set a new record, completing the 3-mile, 1-turn course in 20:00 minutes. Schmitt did not defend his title the following year, and Lavens won with a time of 19:59 minutes, shaving one second off Schmitt's record. Schmitt raced one-on-one against Lavens for the single-sculls championship in 1872, and won (but did not beat Lavens's record). Schmitt sat out 1873, and Lavens won again. The two raced one-on-one again in 1874, and Schmitt won again. Having regained the championship (but not the record) and never having been defeated by Lavens, Schmitt retired from single-sculls competition. But that same year, he and Lavens joined forces to help win the Four-Oared Shell competition for the Pennsylvania Barge Club. Another Eakins painting (unfinished) may commemorate that June 17, 1874 victory. ==The Painting== [[File:Detail max schmitt in a single scull thomas eakins.jpeg|thumb|left|Detail: Eakins's self-portrait.]] Eakins returned to Philadelphia in July 1870, following four years of study at the [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in [[Paris, France|Paris]]. He was a witness to Schmitt's victory in October. The painting's composition echoes the event by reproducing the weather conditions and position of the sun at the date and time of Schmitt's triumph. Rather than in the midst of the competition, Schmitt is depicted nearly at rest – dragging his oars with the disappearing eddies of his course visible in the water. The location is just downstream of the Columbia Railroad Bridge, the site of the turn in the race. Eakins, who was also a keen oarsman, painted himself as the rower in the middle distance. He signed the painting – "Eakins, 1871" – on the stern of his scull.{{cite web|last=Floryan|first=Meg|title=Eakins' The Champion Single Sculls (Max Schmitt In A Single Scull)|url=http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/eakins-the-champion-single-sculls-max-schmitt-in-a-single-scull.html|work=[[Smarthistory]]|publisher=[[Khan Academy]]|accessdate=January 30, 2013}} This was the first of his almost thirty rowing works – sketches, oil paintings, watercolors, perspective drawings – created by the end of 1874.{{cite web|title=Entry to the Real: The Rowing Pictures|url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~hyper/incorp/eakins/rowing.html|work=Cross Roads|publisher=American Studies at the University of Virginia|accessdate=January 30, 2013}} The painting shows the influences of his tutors in France, [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]] and [[Léon Bonnat]], and of [[Diego Velázquez]], the Spanish artist. ==The Reception== The painting was exhibited only once during Eakins's lifetime; at the [[Union League of Philadelphia]] for four days in April 1871. The reviews were mixed. From the ''[[Philadelphia Bulletin]]:''
"The latter artist [Eakins], who has lately returned from Europe and the influence of Gérôme, has also a picture entitled 'The Champion Single Sculls' (No. 137), which, though peculiar, has more than ordinary interest. The Artist, in dealing so boldly and broadly with the commonplace in nature, is working upon well-supported theories, and despite a somewhat scattered effect, gives promise of a conspicuous future."''Philadelphia Bulletin'', April 27, 1871, quoted in [[Gordon Hendricks]], "The Champion Single Sculls", ''Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin'', March 1968, pp. 306-07.[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:Jp3GChTwhy0J:https://12.151.120.44/publications/bulletins/1/pdf/3258339.pdf.bannered.pdf+max+schmitt+philadelphia&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgKueqzf93ECywt7EhXj7FOmWz_6ONa7NifYXGRp59qr-jJ_8BsXtD2y3AzEmfTQqOO-kT8wvvCdD2HpeW1Qu_D7MBHBCRsyEERwgG6AsRi3dVTHXwilvLGlLaKF7pQ91KL9hsi&sig=AHIEtbSvwWK-Is0ZXxDO5adLMxhIvDdwsw]
From the ''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]:''
"Thomas Eakins shows two, a portrait and a river scene, entitled 'The Champion Sculls.' While manifesting a marked ability, especially in the painting of the rower in the foreground, the whole effect is scarcely satisfactory. The light on the water, on the rower and on the trees lining the bank indicates that the sun is blazing fiercely, but on looking upward one perceives a curiously dull leaden sky."''Philadelphia Inquirer'', April 28, 1871, quoted in ''ibid.''
An assessment from 2007:
"This painting, the first of 24 rowing paintings that Eakins completed over the course of four years, was the first time rowing was the focus of serious art. However, the stuffy Philadelphia critics didn’t take well to Eakins’ subject matter, even though rowing was, at the time, one of the most popular sports. A critic remarked that his subject matter was 'a shock to the artistic conventionalities of the city'."Andréa Fernandes. "Feel Art Again: The Champion Single Sculls." ''[[Mental floss]]'' magazine: October 18, 2007.
==Provenance== Eakins gave the painting to his friend Max Schmitt. Following Schmitt's 1900 death, his widow owned it until 1930, when she sold it [[Susan Macdowell Eakins]], the artist's widow.Rob Wilson, "Sculling to the Over-Soul: Louis Simpson, American Transcendentalism, and Thomas Eakins's ''Max Schmitt in a Single Scull''," ''American Quarterly'' (Fall 1987). Mrs. Eakins consigned it to Babcock Galleries, New York City, where it failed to find a buyer. In 1934 it was purchased from Milch Galleries, New York City, by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/10819?=&imgno=0&tabname=object-information Object Information / Provenance], from Metropolitan Museum of Art. File:Detail 2 max schmitt in a single scull thomas eakins.jpeg|Detail: Pennsylvania Railroad Connecting Bridge, with Girard Avenue Bridge beyond. File:Drawing Of Girard Avenue Bridge.jpg|G-44A Eakins's drawing of the Girard Avenue Bridge, [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]]. Image:Sketch of max schmitt in a single scull thomas eakins.jpeg|G-64 Sketch of Max Schmitt (circa 1870-71), [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. File:Oarsmen on the schuylkill thomas eakins.jpeg|G-63 ''Oarsmen on the Schuylkill'' (''The Pennsylvania Barge Four'') (circa 1874), [[Brooklyn Museum]]. From right to left: John Lavens, Jr. (stroke), Max Schmitt, Frank Henderson, Oscar F. West (bow). ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Helen A. Cooper, et al., ''Thomas Eakins: The Rowing Pictures'' (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1996). * Louis Heiland, ''The Schuylkill Navy of Philadelphia, 1858-1937'' (Philadelphia: The Drake Press, 1938). * Theodor Siegl, ''The Thomas Eakins Collection: Philadelphia Museum of Art'' (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1978). ==External links== *[http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/american_paintings_and_sculpture/the_champion_single_sculls_max_schmitt_in_a_single_thomas_eakins/objectview.aspx?collID=2&OID=20011170 Catalogue reference] at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] website. Accession Number: 34.92. *[http://www.livingplaces.com/PA/Philadelphia_County/Philadelphia_City/Boathouse_Row.html Schuylkill Navy History] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/113367 ''The United States of America''], a catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on this painting (p.88-89) {{Eakins}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Max Schmitt In A Single Scull (Painting)}} [[Category:1871 paintings]] [[Category:Portraits by Thomas Eakins|Schmitt, Max]] [[Category:Rowing in the United States]] [[Category:History of rowing]] [[Category:Maritime paintings]] [[Category:American male rowers]] [[Category:Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Sports paintings]]

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=October 2015}} [[File:Max Stern in Germany, c. 1925.jpg|thumbnail|Max Stern in Germany, c. 1925]] '''Max Stern''' (1904-1987) was a [[Germans|German]]-[[Canadians|Canadian]] arts benefactor, art historian, and owner of [[Montreal]]'s landmark Dominion Gallery (in French, ''Galerie Dominion'').
== Life before WWII == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Stern Gallery.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Dr. Max Stern]] --> Max Stern was born in [[Mönchen-Gladbach]], [[Germany]], in April 1904. His father, Julius Stern, was a German-born Jew who worked in the textile industry, and later went into business as an art dealer. Before Max was born, his father was a prestigious art collector, and by [[World War I]], had become one of the most prominent gallery owners in [[Düsseldorf]].<ref name=Pageot>{{cite book|last=Pageot|first=Edith-Anne|title=Max Stern : Montreal Dealer and Patron|year=2004|publisher=Montreal Museum of Fine Arts|location=Montreal|page=15}}</ref> For this reason, Max led a privileged childhood, immersed in Germanic culture. He had his family's full support in pursuing his doctoral studies in art history. He studied in [[Cologne]], [[Berlin]], [[Vienna]] and [[Paris]], and earned his doctorate from the [[University of Bonn]] in 1928.<ref name=Dombowsky>{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=3}}</ref> He then decided to become the Stern Gallery manager. His father died in 1934 and Max became the new gallery owner.<ref name=Pageot />
==During the war== Stern's ambitions grew once he became gallery owner. He hoped to one day operate galleries in [[Düsseldorf]], [[London]] and [[New York City]]. Eventually with the help of his sister and the Dutch art historian Cornelius van de Wetering, Stern managed to open a gallery in [[London]]. The official opening occurred in 1935.<ref name="Dombowsky 5">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=5}}</ref>
Unfortunately, Stern's future plans were disrupted with the rise of [[Nazism]] in Germany. He received notification from the Reich Chamber of Fine Arts that he had lost his [[professional accreditation]], and was given four weeks to either sell or dissolve all holdings within the Galerie Stern.<ref name="MacKenzie 13">{{cite book|last=MacKenzie|first=Catherine Mary|title=Auktion 392 : Reclaiming the Galerie Stern, Dèusseldorf|year=2006|publisher=Concordia University|location=Montreal|page=13}}</ref> He [[appealed]] the [[mandate (criminal law)|mandate]], while trying to find a suitable [[Aryan]] citizen to assume ownership. While the gallery was temporarily "Aryan", Stern planned to open another outside Germany and wait out the [[Third Reich]].<ref name="MacKenzie 13" /> To achieve these means, he chose [[Netherlands|Dutch]] art historian Nathan Katz.
Unfortunately, the Nazi Chamber of Fine Arts decided that the gallery was too important to fall into the hands of a foreigner, and would consider no future deals. In September 1937, Stern was given 17 days to close his business.<ref name="MacKenzie 13" /> The reason for this forced closure was that all [[Jewish]] citizens had been forbidden from selling art. In November, Stern was forced to [[auction]] off a large segment of the Stern Gallery by order of the [[Nazi government]]. These artworks were sold in one of Germany's oldest auction houses, Kunsthaus Lempertz. They went on the block by their lot number, Auktion 392.<ref name=Website>{{cite web|last=Leo Baeck Institute|title="Auktion 392" – Reclaiming the Galerie Stern|url=http://www.lbi.org/2007/02/auktion-392-reclaiming-the-galerie-stern/|publisher=Federal Foreign Office|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> Not all pieces were sold, and Stern placed those that remained in storage with shipping agent Josef Roggendorf. Roggendorf held the artwork close to the Düsseldorf gallery until it was all confiscated by the National Socialist government.<ref name=Dombowsky />
Stern then spent several years trying to track down the 28 confiscated paintings. He created an advertisement in the German art magazine ''Die Weltkunst'', offering a reward for any information pertaining to the paintings' locations.<ref name=Dombowsky /> Recovering the paintings proved to be extremely difficult. ''Musical Party'' by [[Dirck Hals]] and ''Landscape with Figures'' by [[Salomon van Ruysdael]] were eventually recovered with help from the [[Canadian government]] after the war had ended. ''Last Judgment'' by [[Hieronymus Bosch]] was returned in 1954. Other works were never found.<ref name=Dombowsky />
==Post-war== Stern fled Germany in December, 1937, reportedly carrying nothing but a small suitcase. He decided to join his sister at the gallery in London. Their plans to develop further were interrupted a few years later once the war began. Stern was interred as an enemy alien in a [[refugee camp]] on the [[Isle of Man]] for two years.<ref name=Dombowsky /> The British government then allowed him to [[immigrate]] to [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rossouw|first=Henk|title=In Pursuit of an Art Dealer's Dream|year=2006|publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref> Stern sailed on the Polish liner ''Sobiski'',<ref name=Pageot /> but was unable to get his money and belongings out of [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. He then spent two years in [[internment camps]] in [[New Brunswick]] and [[Quebec]].<ref name=Dombowsky /> He was given [[refugee status]] upon his arrival. He took steps to be exempted from this status, and made contact with the man who ran the Canadian Refugee Organization, William Birks, who immediately vouched for Stern.
Because of Stern's academic background and art dealing experience, he was named director of the Dominion Gallery of Fine Art. In January 1947, Stern and his wife became the sole proprietors of Gallery Dominion. He met his wife at the Canadian Refugee organization. She was a Swedish woman named Iris Westerberg.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pageot|first=Edith-Anne|title=Max Stern : Montreal Dealer and Patron|year=2004|publisher=Montreal Museum of Fine Arts|location=Montreal|page=16}}</ref> Together, they made the gallery a focal point for the distribution of living art by Canadian artists. Both were known for promoting young and unknown Canadian art talents.
1944 was an especially important year for Stern's promotion of [[Canadian art]]. During this year, he held separate exhibitions featuring art by four members of the [[Group of Seven (artists)|Group of Seven]] and [[Emily Carr]].<ref name="Dom 5-6">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|pages=5–6}}</ref>
Stern made many important contributions towards Canadian art culture. In the 1940s he provided a means for young Canadian artists to paint on a full-time basis by establishing a contract system. In this system, monthly payments are made to the artist in exchange for an agreed number of works. This method has since been used successfully in [[France]], [[England]] and the [[United States]].<ref name="Dom 5-6" />
In 1950, Stern moved the Dominion Gallery to a three-story building in a different area of Montreal. This new building allowed for 14 exhibition rooms and an apartment on the upper level where Stern and his wife would live.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=6}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:'Ships in Distress on a Stormy Sea' by Jan Porcellis.jpg|thumb|''Ships in a Stormy Sea'', painting by [[Jan Porcellis]] recovered in 2016 and now in the [[Frans Hals Museum]]]] Max Stern is remembered as an icon within the art society worldwide. Upon leaving [[Europe]], Stern raised the level of art appreciation in Canada. He began donating to Canadian institutions in the mid-1950s, and gave generously to several [[museums]] across Canada. He was especially generous to [[Montreal]] institutions, donating over 166 works.<ref name="Dom 7">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=7}}</ref>
True to his occupation until the very end, Stern died on a business trip in [[Paris]]. For his contributions he received countless acknowledgements and awards, including an [[honorary doctorate]] from [[Concordia University]] in 1985. The gallery continued to operate for more than a decade after Stern's death, closing in December 2000.<ref name="Dom 7" />
The [[Max Stern Art Restitution Project]] was jointly created by the [[Hebrew University in Jerusalem]], [[McGill University]], [[Concordia University]] and the Holocaust Claims Processing Office in New York. The project's initiative has been to locate and recover works from the original Stern collection that were lost during the 1930s. The collection held an estimated 400 pieces in total.<ref name="Dr. Max Stern and his Gallery and Art Collection from 1933-1945 and after World War II">{{cite web|last=Korte|first=Willi|title=Dr. Max Stern and his Gallery and Art Collection from 1933-1945 and after World War II|url=https://www.concordia.ca/arts/max-stern/context.html|publisher=Concordia University|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref> Sadly, less than twenty of these paintings have been recovered to date. A long and arduous project, efforts are still being made to recover all Stern pieces lost under the Nazi regime.
In 2017 a scheduled exhibition in Dusseldorf about Stern and the Restitution Project was abruptly cancelled due to local opposition, leading to intense controversy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/art-and-architecture/dusseldorfs-cancellation-of-show-about-jewish-art-dealer-max-stern-sparksoutrage/article37080276/ |title=Restoration drama |last=Angel |first=Sara |date=24 November 2017 |website= |publisher=The Globe and Mail |access-date=13 December 2017 |quote=Dusseldorf's cancellation of show about Jewish art dealer Max Stern sparks outrage}}</ref>
==Selected art pieces donated by Dr. and Mrs. Stern==
* Painting: ''Pensive girl''. Artist: [[Prudence Heward]]. Donated to: [[The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts]]. * Painting: ''The Flayed Woman''. Artist: [[Paul-Emile Borduas]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Little Girl in Blue''. Artist: [[Jori Smith]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Woman on a Sofa''. Artist: [[Kees Van Dongen]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Community House (Ucluelet)''. Artist: [[Emily Carr]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts.
== Artists Stern represented == * [[Jean Arp]] * [[Paul-Émile Borduas]] * [[Emily Carr]] * Stanley Cosgrove * [[Jacques de Tonnancour]] * Louise Gadbois * Francois Gall * [[Eric Goldberg (artist)|Eric Goldberg]] * [[E. J. Hughes]] * [[Wassily Kandinsky]] * J D Lawley * [[Henry Moore]] * [[Gordon Pfeiffer|Gordon Edward Pfeiffer]] * [[Jeanne Rhéaume]] * [[Goodridge Roberts]] * [[Auguste Rodin]] * Marian Scott * [[Paul Soulikias]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vzM2s6FJO-4 "Steppin' Out" (1982). CBC television Montreal Channel 6. 25 November.]</ref> * [[Gentile Tondino]] * [[Tristan Tondino]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.is/20130115085234/http://maxsternproject.concordia.ca/ Max Stern Art Restitution Project] * [http://www.gallery.ca/english/library/biblio/ngc030.html Finding aid, Max Stern fonds, National Gallery of Canada Library and Archives]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stern, Max}} [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:Art and cultural repatriation after World War II]] [[Category:Canadian art dealers]] [[Category:Jewish art collectors]] [[Category:Jewish Canadian artists]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:German art dealers]] [[Category:People interned in the Isle of Man during World War II]] [[Category:Subjects of Nazi art appropriations]]
